definitions.definition: a way of pronouncing the words of a language that shows which country, area or social class a person comes from; how well somebody pronounces a particular language

examples.text: a **strong/broad accent** *(= one that is easy to notice)*
She spoke English with an accent.
The Americans had learned Korean and spoke with a good accent.
He lost his accent after moving to the capital.
He spoke with a cut-glass English accent.
Her French was excellent, without a trace of an accent.
She had a pronounced Scottish accent.
She put on a Southern accent when she answered the phone.
She spoke in a broad Midlands accent.
Where are you from? I can't place your accent.
a tall man with a Canadian accent
It was a fine performance from Diaz, despite her poor Irish accent.

definitions.definition: the emphasis that you should give to part of a word when saying it

examples.text: In ‘today’ the accent is on the second syllable.

definitions.definition: a mark on a letter to show that it should be pronounced in a particular way

examples.text: Canapé has an accent on the ‘e’.

definitions.definition: a special importance that is given to something

examples.text: In all our products **the accent is on** quality.

wordOrigin: late Middle English (in the sense ‘intonation’): from Latin accentus ‘tone, signal, or intensity’ (from ad- ‘to’ + cantus ‘song’), translating Greek prosōidia ‘a song sung to music, intonation’.
